name: Nike
about: Mobile app connecting NBA fans to exclusive content
problem: Everyone wants free merch, but only a select few will be lucky enough to win.
solution: I worked on a front-end feature that allowed users from all over the world to enter a drawing for product prizes and find out if they won (or lost).

name: Booq
about: Mobile app for project managers to secure and book talent
problem: Gigs in the entertainment industry need to be resourced quickly. With so many balls in the air, resources resort to a logistical nightmare of spreadsheets and sticky notes.
solution: I led building architecture of the full-stack app and led a team of two other engineers in rapidly iterating on UI features and user flows after each experiment, while advising the client on technical solutions.

name: Hudson Pacific Properties
about: Web experience for a major, publicly-traded real estate firm
problem: Their look-and-feel had become outdated; further, the site was difficult to navigate and finding properties to lease or buy could be difficult.
solution: I responded to the re-brand team’s demands to build the front-end architecture of the rebuilt web app, and implement SEO optimized server side rendering. I also innovated an intuitive property search feature that integrated with a customized Google map.

name: Jimmy Dorsey Real Estate
about: The world’s first subscription-based realty service app
problem: Historically, real estate industry technology has been limited, clunky and expensive. Entrepreneur Jimmy Dorsey had a dream of disrupting the industry with a modern business plan —and the tech to support it.
solution: I created the app, including implementation of the Stripe Payment API on both client and server and developing business tools to help manage subscribers.

name: Bulma
about: A free, open-source CSS framework based on Flexbox
problem: I love to support new CSS frameworks like Bulma, but I found that there wasn’t documentation on how to create common user interfaces layouts.
solution: I dove deep into the framework and created a set of codepens to share with the React+Bulma community.

name: Varcity Network
about: An educational social network for underprivileged student-athletes.
problem: Black entrepreneurs in Portland have been hit the hardest by recent small business lending drops.
solution: I connected with a local entrepreneur at a pitch event and offered to volunteer to design and build his prototype app. Due, in part, to the strength of this application, he was accepted into the Portland Incubator Experiment (P.I.E.) incubator program and invited to present at Web Summit. Further, this development has inspired my code school to partner with startups on an ongoing basis to provide students with real-world practice.
